Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer: A Hub for Fundamental Interdisciplinary Chemical Research, Applications, and Research Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Hampshire College (Amherst, MA) to acquire and install an inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). The new generation ICP-MS will make possible a wide range of research projects, particularly focused on pollution and nutrition, while training a diverse group of undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research. Some of the advances that will benefit the general public include the identification and quantification of toxic trace metal pollutants such as arsenic, antimony, cadmium, and lead in present and past environments and analysis of the tissue-level uptake and incorporation of nutritionally important elements such as zinc and iron in human teeth and hair. ICP-MS will also be used to develop novel methods to track the fate, transport, and translocation of toxic metal contaminants and metal nano particles in the environment and in biological tissues. These analytical chemical advances will facilitate better environmental monitoring methods for water and food systems that will improve public health and will support food security. The ICP-MS will allow the researchers to engage and support new and existing research partnerships across the Five College Consortium, as well as to enhance collaborations with broader regional and international academic institutions to address larger environmental health research questions of national and global interest.

This project is driven by a team of core faculty, who seek to achieve three planned undergraduate research and curricula advances: (1) incorporation of the ICP-MS, with accompanying advances in atomic spectrometry techniques [laser ablation (LA)-ICP-MS, ion chromatography (IC)-ICP-MS], as part of the proposed interdisciplinary research projects; (2) expansion of the scope of undergraduate interdisciplinary research projects based on the ability of ICP-MS to investigate possible toxic metalloid adsorption properties of clay supported nano zero valent ion particles, the fate and transport properties of engineered nano particles (ENP), tissue level distributions of toxic metals in archived tissues of teeth and hair to unravel past exposure events, elemental bioimaging of staple food grains to gain insight on nutritional benefits and health risks at tissue level, the geo-microbiology of rock varnishes; and (3) incorporation of state-of-the-art atomic spectrometry methods across the undergraduate curriculum, including within courses and independent projects. Proposed projects center on analytical atomic spectrometry, analytical method development, and validation. The developed methods will be applied in a variety of innovative interdisciplinary research projects conducted by student-faculty research teams that will advance the environmental health monitoring efforts. Major findings and data from research will be presented by students and faculty at national and international meetings and published in peer-reviewed journals. As well, the results will be disseminated to the public via local outreach efforts and popular media forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We successfully installed a Perkin Elmer NexION 2000B inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS).  This state-of-the-art instrument updated a twenty-year-old ICP-MS.  It has allowed us to advance a range of research projects centered on measurement of the chemical composition of biological and environmental materials.  Thus far, our completed project has the following potential public benefits: analytical chemistry developments for identification and monitoring of past and present toxic trace metal pollution events; tissue-level spatial elemental imaging of biological materials; new methods to reveal the fate, transport, and translocation of toxic metal contaminants and metal nano particles in the environment; and new techniques to sequester metal contaminants.

The ICP-MS enabled us to train a diverse group of undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research via course-based and independent research projects. We specifically completed the following chemistry-related interdisciplinary research projects, particularly focused on pollution and nutrition.

First, we have demonstrated the ability to remove the toxic elements cadmium (Cd), copper (Cu), iron (Fe), lead (Pb) and zinc (Zn) from contaminated soils and acid mine water using pristine rice husks. The physical and chemical mechanisms of adsorption of these elements by rice husks were also established. Thus, a readily available agricultural waste product, rice husk, has been determined to be an effective and economical material to use to mitigate contaminated water and soils.

Second, we demonstrated the ability to remediate Pb, antimony (Sb) and arsenic (As) in a contaminated apple orchard, a shooting range, and mining soils using nano technology (i.e., kaolin-coated nano zero valent iron (K-nZVI).

Third, we have developed an analytical method to determine lithium (Li), boron (B), Pb, and As concentrations in archeological hair using laser ablation (LA)-ICP-MS. This method offers several benefits including speed, sensitivity and accuracy. Our method was successfully used to study the environmental exposure of ancient Andeans who lived in geogenic areas rich in Li, B, Pb and As. Additionally, this study would help researchers to comprehend the potential for Li exposure of contemporary populations via increased usage of lithium-containing consumer products and electric storage battery wastes.  In an article summarizing our work on mummy hair analysis for geogenic elements, we discussed the arsenic exposure of ancient Andeans and their potential ability to adapt to living in arsenic-rich environments.

Fourth, we also developed a method to visually observe tissue-level toxic and essential elements by LA-ICP-MS as well as to examine the fate and translocation properties of essential (i.e., Zn) and toxic (i.e., As, Cd, Sb) elements during the early stages of corn seed germination. Spatial elemental distribution analysis of corn seed tissue regions revealed that the highest concentrations of elements generally accumulate in the pericarp and germ tissues of the corn seed as compared to the starchy endosperm (i.e., edible part). These findings suggest the removal of corn pericarp (i.e., hulling) lessens the potential health risks related to consumption of contaminated corn.

Fifth, we demonstrated the ability to determine past pollution events in a mining area using LA-ICP-MS and elemental dendrochronology.

Finally, the distribution of various critical, strategic, and toxic elements contained within several components of discarded mobile smart phones was identified using LA-ICP-MS, and the importance of recovery of those valuable elements in electronic components was emphasized.  

In conclusion, we believe that the analytical chemical advances discussed above will facilitate better and sensitive toxic metal(loid)s monitoring methods for water, soil, food, and solid waste that will improve public health and will enhance food safety and environmental sustainability. The resulting broader scientific developments will improve public health monitoring work and will support agriculture, food and environmental security.
